Comment_contributor: If the native begins with the little finger of the left hand he will call it monou, one
but he may add to it the next finger and call them morere, two or he may say they are “two.”
The third finger he naims kai; ane is the conjunction “and,” hence rere kaiane means little finger and the fourth are two fingers and kai added to them they become three fingers.

Morere-morere suggests that these natives are inclined to think in pairs or couples; they certainly do group the fingers into two pairs when they wish to illustrate what they mean by “four.” Taking it that they count thus, morere, one pair, morere-morere, another pair. The mo is in frequent use and means “ another,” “more.”
Kaupu, five, i.e., a collection or company, i.e., the fingers of the clenched hand.
